awd_titl_txt: Nanomanufacturing of Vertically Aligned Carbon Nanotube Arrays from Industrial Waste Gas Mixture
awd_abstract_narration:
Although significant progress has been made in the past two decades in scaling up carbon nanotube manufacture via chemical vapor deposition, the process still faces key challenges such as poor yield due to short catalyst lifetime, low nanotube nucleation density, slow production rate, variations in nanotube properties, resulting in high cost of the nanotubes. Chemical vapor deposition is often plagued by complicated optimization procedures due to the high sensitivity of the growth process to variations in the feedstock composition and flow characteristics. For energy applications that exploit the intrinsic electrical and thermal anisotropy of carbon nanotubes, such as thermal interface materials and battery electrodes, organized nanotube architectures are required to be grown directly on conductive substrates that hardly support growth. This award paves the way for an industrial waste-gas mixture to be used as a feedstock for scalable, low-cost, and continuous manufacture of high-quality carbon nanotube arrays on nontraditional substrates. The use of this feedstock for nanotube growth minimizes the amount of flue gases in oil refineries, thus enhancing environmental protection. The study provides a platform for educating students at many levels, including women and under-represented minorities, on topics related to nanoscience, nanotechnology and nanomanufacturing.

The project develops the fundamental understanding required to couple catalytic chemical vapor deposition to the waste stream of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) process for scalable and controlled growth of carbon nanotube (CNT) arrays. The project research plan combines reaction engineering through modification of gas-phase chemistry, rational catalyst substrate modification, and advanced ex situ and in situ characterization of catalysts and CNT arrays. The resulting understanding of the roles of the waste-gas mixture and catalyst-substrate interactions in CNT growth enhancement provides a rational basis for optimization and scale-up of CNT growth on nontraditional substrates. Unlike conventional feedstocks that require strict process control and growth rate, area density of CNTs and their quality are generally less sensitive to the fraction of the waste gas during growth, and thus allow for easy optimization and scale-up. The research is expected to contribute in-depth understanding of catalyst-substrate interactions, catalyst evolution under different reaction conditions, and gas-phase chemistries during CNT growth. This study has the distinct possibility of having broad implications in multiple applications, including energy storage and thermal management.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Our goal of coupling the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process to the waste stream of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) process for efficient, continuous, and scalable production of carbon nanotube (CNT) arrays using the gaseous waste mixture from FTS (FTS-GP) as a feedstock requires a good understanding of the process. Our study has illuminated the role of feedstock (FTS-GP) during CNT growth. The results from experiments and thermodynamic calculations reveal that the superior catalytic activity observed during our modified CVD process is due to in situ water formation in the vicinity of the catalyst. The graphical abstract of the study (Figure 1) shows how catalyst lifetime and stability are enhanced due to the on-site generation of water.  The temperature was found to be a key factor in influencing catalyst lifetime because the amount of water formed via the reaction between H2 and CO decreases with increasing temperature. The growth enhancement observed during our modified CVD process (FTS-GP CVD) was successfully explained. The mechanistic understanding of FTS-GP CVD process developed through this effort will support efforts toward process optimization and scalable manufacturing of CNTs.

CNT growth behavior is not only sensitive to the feedstock type but also highly sensitive to the properties of the catalyst substrate. CNT carpet growth on traditional substrates such as MgO, TiO2, ZrO2, SiO2, and zeolite has largely failed to mimic the high growth efficiency routinely obtained on amorphous alumina films. To study the effect of substrate properties, we used ion beam bombardment to modify the substrate. In addition, substrates (MgAl2O4 and MgO) with different crystal phases were used. Our results reveal that ion beam bombardment effectively transforms an "inactive" substrate into an "active" substrate for CNT growth. In general, FTS-GP outperforms ethylene in terms of growth rate and lifetime of catalyst supported on the different MgAl2O4 substrates.

 In addition to conducting growth on metal substrates, we investigated CNT growth from Fe catalyst supported on new-generation basic catalyst supports that have shown promise in several heterogeneous catalytic reactions: MgAl2O4 and MgO (100). Using different crystal phases of and the alumina family of substrates (c-cut sapphire and amorphous films) we were able to investigate the effect of basicity and surface energies on CNT growth. Different phases of MgAl2O4 substrates show different CNT growth behavior due to their different surface chemistries and surface energies. Among the different phases of MgAl2O4, ion beam-damaged MgAl2O4 (111) is the best supporting layer, most likely due to its atomic stacking sequence, which makes it highly basic. This work further clarifies the critical role of catalyst-substrate interactions and shows that the interactions and resulting CNT growth behavior are affected by the different atomic surface arrangements that exist in the catalyst substrate. This insight will incentivize researchers to start exploring the tailoring of physicochemical properties of substrates for controlling CNT geometry.

We employed an autonomous research system (ARES) at the Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL), equipped with in situ Raman spectroscopy, to probe the secret role of FTS-GP in enhancing catalyst lifetime and growth efficiency. ARES allows for rapid, automated experimentation to maximize growth rate based on previous results. The ARES data support our mechanistic rationale for the observed growth enhancement with FTS-GP CVD. The ARES experiments reveal FTS-GP not only exhibits exceptionally long catalyst lifetimes compared to a standard feedstock (ethylene) but also shows a high tolerance for relatively high levels of water. For both feedstocks, the growth rate was found to decrease with an increasing amount of additional water in the reactor, albeit with a higher decrease in the case of ethylene. Conversely, unlike ethylene CVD, additional water in the reactor during FTS-GP CVD led to a significant increase in lifetime. The new insights into how catalyst properties affect the composition of FTS-GP and how changes in FTS-GP composition ultimately affect CNT growth will be valuable in designing CVD reactors for the scalable growth of CNTs. The use of ARES has provided critical insights into reaction conditions optimum for the growth of CNTs with different properties and the role of water during FTS-GP CVD.

Our efforts to develop a scalable process for producing carbon nanotubes led to our successful demonstration of the use of supercritical fluids as reaction media for the scalable and selective growth of carbon nanomaterials in a batch reactor. The batch reactor process utilizes toluene and alcohols (ethanol, propanol, and butanol) as carbon precursors in combination with ferrocene and yields a variety of nanocarbons including CNTs, fibers, and onion-like carbons with improved product selectivity. The onion-like graphitic structures are currently being evaluated as electrode material in supercapacitors. This study provides a framework for utilizing supercritical fluid reaction media for the mass production of nanocarbons and nanocarbon−metal nanocomposites.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Placidus B Amama

Image
  • The graphical abstract (cover page of I&EC Research) illustrates the mechanism for the CNT growth enhancement observed during FTS-GP CVD: high flux of carbon atoms to the catalyst particles and on-site generation of water to prevent coking of catalyst.
